newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian energy use growth slowing - ABARE.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian energy use growth slowing - ABARE.

text.p: The rate of growth of Australian energy consumption is slowing due in part to more efficient uses of energy, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) said on Wednesday.
Consumption growth is projected to average 2.1 percent a year to 2010, compared with 2.5 percent a year over the past two decades, ABARE said.
Economic growth, improved energy efficiencies and the switch to different fuel types are factors underpinning the decline, the forecasting agency said.
While crude oil is expected to remain the major fuel used in Australia, usage of natural gas is projected to increase to 28 percent by 2010 from 18 percent currently.
Growth in natural gas usage is largely being driven by an expanding gas pipeline nertwork in Australia, which is making the fuel source more widely available, ABARE said.
Reforms in natural gas and electricity markets are also leading to opportunities for private investment in the electricity generation and cogeneration sectors, the agency said.
These reforms are enabling producers of natural gas to negotiate directly with buyers, leading to more competitive pricing, ABARE said.
Australia's focus on exporting the majority of its energy is forecast to remain a key factor for domestic producers, with over 75 percent of total output earmarked for export by 2010.
Black coal, and increasingly uranium, will dominate Australian production and trade in the energy sector.
However, strong growth in natural gas production and trade is also set to continue, it added.
